A traditional Italian recipe for authentic pasta carbonara with eggs, cheese, and guanciale.
Carbonara is one of Rome's four classic pasta dishes (
pasta alla carbonara, cacio e pepe, amatriciana, gricia
), and when made properly, it's pure magicâ€”silky, rich, and deeply savory.
Step 1: Prepare the Cheese and Egg Mixture
Combine the egg yolks, whole egg, grated Pecorino, and Parmigiano in a large mixing bowl
This recipe contains no cream, garlic, or onions. Those are common misconceptions about carbonara. The sauce is made entirely from eggs, cheese, and pasta water.
Add a generous amount of freshly ground black pepper (at least 1 teaspoon)
Whisk vigorously until smooth and creamyâ€”it should look like a thick, pale yellow cream
Do this first so the mixture isn't cold when you add the pasta.
Cut the guanciale into small strips or lardons (about 0.5cm thick)
Add to a cold panâ€”no oil needed, the fat will render out
Turn heat to medium-low and cook slowly for 8-10 minutes
The guanciale should become golden and crispy, with plenty of rendered fat
Turn off the heat and set aside (keep it in the pan)
Bring a large pot of water to a rolling boil
Add salt (about 1 tablespoon per literâ€”the water should taste like the sea)
Reserve at least 1 cup of pasta cooking water
Do not drain the pasta completelyâ€”keep it slightly wet
This is the critical stepâ€”timing and temperature are everything:
Add the hot, wet pasta directly to the pan with guanciale
Toss quickly to coat the pasta with the fat (heat should be
Let the pasta cool for about
(you should be able to comfortably touch the pan)
Add the egg and cheese mixture and start tossing immediately
Add pasta water a little at a time (2-3 tablespoons initially) while tossing constantly
Keep tossing and adding water until you achieve a creamy, glossy sauce that coats the pasta
Starting with a cold pan allows the fat to render slowly without burning the meat.
Silky and creamy (not watery, not clumpy)
Flows slightly when you tilt the bowl
Finish with more freshly ground black pepper
Serve right away (carbonara waits for no one)
The key to carbonara is creating a stable emulsion between the eggs, cheese, fat, and pasta water:
Eggs scramble and you get clumps
Sauce won't emulsify and remains watery
Around 70-80Â°C (160-175Â°F)â€”warm enough to thicken but not cook the eggs
It thins the sauce to the right consistency
Pecorino Romano is sheep's milk cheeseâ€”it's sharper and saltier than Parmigiano. This saltiness is traditional and essential to the flavor profile.
Common Mistakes and How to Avoid Them
Added eggs to pasta that was too hot
Let the pasta cool for 30 seconds after removing from heat
Not enough pasta water or added too quickly
Add water gradually while tossing constantly
Too much pasta water or pasta was too cool
Use less water and ensure pasta is still hot
Not enough cheese, pepper, or guanciale fat
Don't skimp on ingredients; season generously
Can I use bacon instead of guanciale?
is cured pork jowlâ€”fattier and more flavorful than bacon.
(cured pork belly) is the closest substitute. Regular bacon works but will have a smokier, less traditional flavor.
Pecorino Romano is traditional, but you can use all Parmigiano if needed. Just add extra salt since Parmigiano is milder.
Traditionalists will say no. The "creaminess" comes from the eggs and pasta water emulsion. Adding cream makes it a different dish (though still delicious).
While purists stick to the classic, some variations include:
Using different pasta shapes (rigatoni is traditional in Rome)
Adding a touch of white wine to the guanciale
Carbonara is a fast dishâ€”the active cooking time is only about 15 minutes:
The beauty of carbonara is its simplicityâ€”just a few quality ingredients, proper technique, and respect for tradition.
